trial_identification.studytitle: How do thick airway walls affect airway hyperresponsiveness in asthma.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect in asthmatic subjects of changes in airway wall thickness induced by inhaled corticosteroids on airway hyperresponsiveness
trial_identification.secondaryid: National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Grant No: X08-0072

interventions.interventions: All subjects will be treated with fluticasone as inhaled combination therapy (Seretide) at 500ug twice daily (bd) for twelve weeks

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in airway wall thickness, measured using high resoution computed tomography (HRCT) scans, during 3 months treatment correlates with a change in airway responsiveness, measured using methacholine bronchial challenge tests.
correlation between airway stiffness, measured using the forced oscillation technique, and airway responsiveness, measured using methacholine bronchial challenge tests
primaryOutcome.timepoint: before and after 3 months of treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: correlation between airway wall thickening, measured using high resoution computed tomography (HRCT) scans, and airway stiffness, measured using the forced oscillation technique.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: before and after 3 months of treatment

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: doctor-diagnosed asthma; current symptoms of asthma; airway hyperresponsiveness to methacholine; taking no more than 800ug Beclomethasone diproprionate (BDP) equivalent/day;
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: current smokers within the last year or having more than 10 years pack history; pregnancy; history of lung cancer, lung reduction surgery, major illness (heart attack, stroke, epilepsy, rheumatoid arthritis); respiratory infection or oral pregnisolone use within the four weeks prior to study participation

trial_design.designfeatures: Only one treatment intervention was used and this was only for those participants who were suitable for treatment (they had to have airway hyperresponsiveness and current symptoms and/or taking current treatment for their asthma)

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The Woolcock Institute of Medical Research

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Asthmatic airways narrow too easily, a characteristic called airway hyperresponsiveness (AHR). To understand the cause of asthma we need to understand the cause of AHR. Thickened airway walls could amplify airway narrowing and increase AHR. However, thick airway walls are also stiff, and stiff walls could reduce narrowing and AHR. This projnect will examine the relationships between AHR and airway wall thickness and stiffness during and after treatment that reduces airway wall thickness. Airway wall thickness will be measured by high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scan of the chest. Airway stiffness will be measured using a simple breathing test. Measurements will be made at baseline and after six and twelve weeks of treatment. Treatment with inhaled corticosteroids over twelve weeks will be used to reduce airway inflammation and airway wall thickness. These drugs are recommended in all asthma management guidelines for the treatment of asthma, and will be used in standard, recommended doses.
